title: Adam Sandler and Jennifer Aniston to star in Murder Mystery sequel
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Adam Sandler and Jennifer Aniston are set to reunite for a Murder Mystery sequel which isn’t at all surprising considering over 30 million accounts watched the comedy in its first weekend.

Yep, the Netflix comedy about the pair who played a New York police officer and his wife, who find themselves as prime suspects in the murder of an elderly billionaire during a trip to Europe, will return for a second whodunnit with James Vanderbilt in negotiations to once again pen the script.

The original movie was directed by Kyle Newache and co-starred Luke Evans and Terence Stamp.

It was Sandler’s sixth Netflix movie as part of his deal with the online streaming service – sealed via his own Happy Madison Productions – following The Ridiculous Six, The Do-Over, Sandy Wexler, The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected), and The Week Of.

The release of Murder Mystery in July gave Netflix their biggest opening weekend ever (Picture: NETFLIX)

After signing a deal with Netflix, Adam said: ‘I love how passionate they are about making movies and getting them out there for the whole world to see. They’ve made me feel like family and I can’t thank them enough for their support.’

The release of Murder Mystery in July gave Netflix their biggest opening weekend ever, with over 30 million accounts watching the comedy.

The original movie co-starred Luke Evans (Picture: NETFLIX)

Netflix, who are notoriously cagey about releasing their data, have revealed that ‘30,869,863 accounts watched Murder Mystery’ in the first three days, which is officially ‘the biggest opening weekend ever for a Netflix Film’.

Those figures are broken down into ‘13,374,914 accounts in the US and Canada, and 17,494,949 more worldwide’.

Netflix data works on the premise that 70% of a film has to have been watched to count in the final figures. The numbers will be a boost to the streaming service however, who in 2015 signed a four-film deal with Sandler, despite his box office numbers dropping steadily in recent years.
